name: Neo4j
title: A Neo4j cheat sheet with getting started resources and information on how to query the database with Cypher.

cards.title: Intro
cards.body: A Neo4j cheat sheet with getting started resources and information on how to query the database with Cypher.

cards.title: Getting Started with Neo4j
cards.body:
Neo4j is a Graph Database consisting of nodes connected together by relationships. You might consider using a Graph
database if you have a highly connected dataset or have queries with many joins.

cards.title: Getting Started with Neo4j
cards.body:
• [Download Neo4j Desktop](https://neo4j.com/download) _download Neo4j desktop or server editions_
• [Neo4j Sandbox](https://sandbox.neo4j.com) _pick a data set - no installation required_
• [Neo4j Aura](https://neo4j.com/aura) _free Neo4j instance in the cloud_
• [Neo4j GraphAcademy](https://neo4j.com/graphacademy) _free, self-paced, hands-on online training_
• [GraphGists](https://neo4j.com/graphgists) _use ase and industry specific example graphs_

cards.title: Graph Database Concepts
cards.back: Nodes are commonly used to represent _entities_ or _things_ in your data. For example, a **Person** or **Movie**

cards.title: Graph Database Concepts
cards.back: Relationships are used to connect two nodes together and organise the data into structure. For example, a Person **acted in** a movie. A relationship has a _type_ and _direction_, although the direction can be ignored at query time.

cards.title: Graph Database Concepts
cards.back: Labels are used to group nodes into categories. For example, a person may have `Person` and `Actor` labels.

cards.title: Graph Database Concepts
cards.back: Each relationship has a type. Relationships allow you to explore smaller sections of a graph.

cards.title: Graph Database Concepts
cards.back: Both nodes and relationships can have properties set against them. Properties are [name-value pairs](https://neo4j.com/docs/cypher-manual/4.3/syntax/values/#cypher-values).

cards.title: Read query structure
cards.code:
[USE]
[MATCH WHERE]
[OPTIONAL MATCH WHERE]
[WITH [ORDER BY] [SKIP] [LIMIT]]
RETURN [ORDER BY] [SKIP] [LIMIT]

cards.title: Read-write query structure
cards.code:
[USE]
[MATCH WHERE]
[OPTIONAL MATCH WHERE]
[WITH [ORDER BY] [SKIP] [LIMIT]]
(CREATE | MERGE)*
[SET|DELETE|REMOVE|FOREACH]*
[RETURN [ORDER BY] [SKIP] [LIMIT]]

cards.title: MATCH
cards.body: Node patterns can contain labels and properties.

cards.title: MATCH
cards.body: Any pattern can be used in MATCH.

cards.title: MATCH
cards.body: Patterns with node properties.

cards.title: MATCH
cards.body: Assign a path to p.

cards.title: MATCH
cards.body: Optional pattern: nulls will be used for missing parts.

cards.title: WHERE
cards.body:
Use a predicate to filter. Note that WHERE is always part of a MATCH, OPTIONAL MATCH or WITH clause. Putting it after a
different clause in a query will alter what it does.

cards.title: WHERE
WHERE
cards.body: Use an existential subquery to filter.

cards.title: RETURN
cards.body: Return the value of all variables.

cards.title: RETURN
cards.body: Use alias for result column name.

cards.title: RETURN
cards.body: Return unique rows.

cards.title: RETURN
cards.body: Sort the result.

cards.title: RETURN
cards.body: Sort the result in descending order.

cards.title: RETURN
cards.body: Skip a number of results.

cards.title: RETURN
cards.body: Limit the number of results.

cards.title: RETURN
cards.body: Skip results at the top and limit the number of results.

cards.title: RETURN
cards.body: The number of matching rows. See Aggregating functions for more.

cards.title: WITH
cards.code:
MATCH (user)-[:FRIEND]-(friend)
WHERE user.name = $name
WITH user, count(friend) AS friends
WHERE friends > 10
RETURN user

cards.title: WITH
cards.body:
The WITH syntax is similar to RETURN. It separates query parts explicitly, allowing you to declare which variables to
carry over to the next part.

cards.title: WITH
cards.code:
MATCH (user)-[:FRIEND]-(friend)
WITH user, count(friend) AS friends
ORDER BY friends DESC
  SKIP 1
  LIMIT 3
RETURN user

cards.title: WITH
cards.body: ORDER BY, SKIP, and LIMIT can also be used with WITH.

cards.title: UNION
cards.code:
MATCH (a)-[:KNOWS]->(b)
RETURN b.name
UNION
MATCH (a)-[:LOVES]->(b)
RETURN b.name

cards.title: UNION
cards.body: Returns the distinct union of all query results. Result column types and names have to match.

cards.title: UNION
cards.code:
MATCH (a)-[:KNOWS]->(b)
RETURN b.name
UNION ALL
MATCH (a)-[:LOVES]->(b)
RETURN b.name

cards.title: UNION
cards.body: Returns the union of all query results, including duplicated rows.

cards.title: CREATE
cards.body: Create a node with the given properties.

cards.title: CREATE
cards.body: Create a node with the given properties.

cards.title: CREATE
cards.code:
UNWIND $listOfMaps AS properties
CREATE (n) SET n = properties

cards.title: CREATE
cards.body: Create nodes with the given properties.

cards.title: CREATE
cards.body: Create a relationship with the given type and direction; bind a variable to it.

cards.title: CREATE
cards.body: Create a relationship with the given type, direction, and properties.

cards.title: SET
cards.body: Update or create a property.

cards.title: SET
cards.body: Set all properties. This will remove any existing properties.

cards.title: SET
cards.body: Add and update properties, while keeping existing ones.

cards.title: SET
cards.body: Adds a label Person to a node.

cards.title: MERGE
cards.code:
MERGE (n:Person {name: $value})
  ON CREATE SET n.created = timestamp()
  ON MATCH SET
    n.counter = coalesce(n.counter, 0) + 1,
    n.accessTime = timestamp()

cards.title: MERGE
cards.body: Match a pattern or create it if it does not exist. Use ON CREATE and ON MATCH for conditional updates.

cards.title: MERGE
cards.body: MERGE finds or creates a relationship between the nodes.

cards.title: MERGE
cards.body: MERGE finds or creates paths attached to the node.

cards.title: DELETE
cards.body: Delete a node and a relationship.

cards.title: DELETE
cards.body: Delete a node and all relationships connected to it.

cards.title: DELETE
cards.body: Delete all nodes and relationships from the database.

cards.title: REMOVE
cards.body: Remove a label from n.

cards.title: REMOVE
cards.body: Remove a property.

cards.title: FOREACH
cards.code:
FOREACH (r IN relationships(path) |
  SET r.marked = true)

cards.title: FOREACH
cards.body: Execute a mutating operation for each relationship in a path.

cards.title: FOREACH
cards.body: Execute a mutating operation for each element in a list.

cards.title: CALL subquery
CALL subquery
cards.body: This calls a subquery with two union parts. The result of the subquery can afterwards be post-processed.

cards.title: CALL procedure
cards.body:
This shows a standalone call to the built-in procedure db.labels to list all labels used in the database. Note that
required procedure arguments are given explicitly in brackets after the procedure name.

cards.title: CALL procedure
cards.body: Standalone calls may use YIELD \* to return all columns.

cards.title: CALL procedure
cards.body:
Standalone calls may omit YIELD and also provide arguments implicitly via statement parameters, e.g. a standalone call
requiring one argument input may be run by passing the parameter map {input: 'foo'}.

cards.title: CALL procedure
cards.code:
CALL db.labels() YIELD label
RETURN count(label) AS count

cards.title: CALL procedure
cards.body:
Calls the built-in procedure db.labels inside a larger query to count all labels used in the database. Calls inside a
larger query always requires passing arguments and naming results explicitly with YIELD.

cards.title: Import
cards.code:
LOAD CSV FROM
'https://neo4j.com/docs/cypher-refcard/4.3/csv/artists.csv' AS line
CREATE (:Artist {name: line[1], year: toInteger(line[2])})

cards.title: Import
cards.body: Load data from a CSV file and create nodes.

cards.title: Import
cards.code:
LOAD CSV WITH HEADERS FROM
'https://neo4j.com/docs/cypher-refcard/4.3/csv/artists-with-headers.csv' AS line
CREATE (:Artist {name: line.Name, year: toInteger(line.Year)})

cards.title: Import
cards.body: Load CSV data which has headers.

cards.title: Import
cards.code:
USING PERIODIC COMMIT 500
LOAD CSV WITH HEADERS FROM
'https://neo4j.com/docs/cypher-refcard/4.3/csv/artists-with-headers.csv' AS line
CREATE (:Artist {name: line.Name, year: toInteger(line.Year)})

cards.title: Import
cards.body: Commit the current transaction after every 500 rows when importing large amounts of data.

cards.title: Import
cards.code:
LOAD CSV FROM
'https://neo4j.com/docs/cypher-refcard/4.3/csv/artists-fieldterminator.csv'
AS line FIELDTERMINATOR ';'
CREATE (:Artist {name: line[1], year: toInteger(line[2])})

cards.title: Import
cards.body: Use a different field terminator, not the default which is a comma (with no whitespace around it).

cards.title: Import
cards.code:
LOAD CSV FROM
'https://neo4j.com/docs/cypher-refcard/4.3/csv/artists.csv' AS line
RETURN DISTINCT file()

cards.title: Import
cards.body: Returns the absolute path of the file that LOAD CSV is processing, returns null if called outside of LOAD CSV context.

cards.title: Import
cards.code:
LOAD CSV FROM
'https://neo4j.com/docs/cypher-refcard/4.3/csv/artists.csv' AS line
RETURN linenumber()

cards.title: Import
cards.body: Returns the line number that LOAD CSV is currently processing, returns null if called outside of LOAD CSV context.

cards.title: null
cards.body: • `null` is used to represent missing/undefined values.

cards.title: null
cards.body: • `null` is not equal to `null`. Not knowing two values does not imply that they are the same value. So the expression

cards.title: null
cards.body: `null = null` yields `null` and not `true`. To check if an expression is `null`, use `IS NULL`.

cards.title: null
cards.body: • Arithmetic expressions, comparisons and function calls (except `coalesce`) will return `null` if any argument is

cards.title: null
cards.body: `null`.

cards.title: null
cards.body:
• An attempt to access a missing element in a list or a property that doesn’t exist yields `null`.
• In `OPTIONAL MATCH` clauses, `nulls` will be used for missing parts of the pattern.

cards.title: Patterns
cards.body: Node with Person label.

cards.title: Patterns
cards.body: Node with both Person and Swedish labels.

cards.title: Patterns
cards.body: Node with the declared properties.

cards.title: Patterns
cards.body: Matches relationships with the declared properties.

cards.title: Patterns
cards.body: Relationship from n to m.

cards.title: Patterns
cards.body: Relationship in any direction between n and m.

cards.title: Patterns
cards.body: Node n labeled Person with relationship to m.

cards.title: Patterns
cards.body: Relationship of type KNOWS from n to m.

cards.title: Patterns
cards.body: Relationship of type KNOWS or of type LOVES from n to m.

cards.title: Patterns
cards.body: Bind the relationship to variable r.

cards.title: Patterns
cards.body: Variable length path of between 1 and 5 relationships from n to m.

cards.title: Patterns
cards.body: Variable length path of any number of relationships from n to m. (See Performance section.)

cards.title: Patterns
cards.body: A relationship of type KNOWS from a node n to a node m with the declared property.

cards.title: Patterns
cards.body: Find a single shortest path.

cards.title: Patterns
cards.body: Find all shortest paths.

cards.title: Patterns
cards.body: Count the paths matching the pattern.

cards.title: USE
cards.body: Select myDatabase to execute query, or query part, against.

cards.title: USE
cards.body: MATCH query executed against neo4j database.

cards.title: SHOW FUNCTIONS and PROCEDURES
cards.body: Listing all available functions.

cards.title: SHOW FUNCTIONS and PROCEDURES
cards.body: List all procedures that can be executed by the current user and return only the name of the procedures.

cards.title: Labels
cards.body: Create a node with label and property.

cards.title: Labels
cards.body: Matches or creates unique node(s) with the label and property.

cards.title: Labels
cards.body: Add label(s) to a node.

cards.title: Labels
cards.body: Matches nodes labeled Person.

cards.title: Labels
cards.body: Matches nodes labeled Person with the given name.

cards.title: Labels
cards.body: Checks the existence of the label on the node.

cards.title: Labels
cards.body: Labels of the node.

cards.title: Labels
cards.body: Remove the label from the node.

cards.title: Lists
cards.body: Literal lists are declared in square brackets.

cards.title: Lists
cards.body: Lists can be passed in as parameters.

cards.title: Lists
cards.body:
range() creates a list of numbers (step is optional), other functions returning lists are: labels(), nodes(),
relationships().

cards.title: Lists
cards.code:
MATCH p = (a)-[:KNOWS*]->()
RETURN relationships(p) AS r

cards.title: Lists
cards.body: The list of relationships comprising a variable length path can be returned using named paths and relationships().

cards.title: Lists
cards.code:
RETURN matchedNode.list[0] AS value,
       size(matchedNode.list) AS len

cards.title: Lists
cards.body: Properties can be lists of strings, numbers or booleans.

cards.title: Lists
cards.code:
list[$idx] AS value,
list[$startIdx..$endIdx] AS slice

cards.title: Lists
cards.body:
List elements can be accessed with idx subscripts in square brackets. Invalid indexes return null. Slices can be
retrieved with intervals from start_idx to end_idx, each of which can be omitted or negative. Out of range elements are
ignored.

cards.title: Lists
cards.code:
UNWIND $names AS name
MATCH (n {name: name})
RETURN avg(n.age)

cards.title: Lists
cards.body: With UNWIND, any list can be transformed back into individual rows. The example matches all names from a list of names.

cards.title: Lists
cards.body: Pattern comprehensions may be used to do a custom projection from a match directly into a list.

cards.title: Lists
cards.body: Map projections may be easily constructed from nodes, relationships and other map values.

cards.title: Maps
cards.body: Literal maps are declared in curly braces much like property maps. Lists are supported.

cards.title: Maps
cards.code:
WITH {person: {name: 'Anne', age: 25}} AS p
RETURN p.person.name

cards.title: Maps
cards.body: Access the property of a nested map.

cards.title: Maps
cards.body: Maps can be passed in as parameters and used either as a map or by accessing keys.

cards.title: Maps
cards.body: Nodes and relationships are returned as maps of their data.

cards.title: Maps
cards.body: Map entries can be accessed by their keys. Invalid keys result in an error.

cards.title: Predicates
cards.body: Use comparison operators.

cards.title: Predicates
cards.body: Use functions.

cards.title: Predicates
cards.body: Use boolean operators to combine predicates.

cards.title: Predicates
cards.body: Use chained operators to combine predicates.

cards.title: Predicates
cards.body: Check for node labels.

cards.title: Predicates
cards.body: Check if something is not null, e.g. that a property exists.

cards.title: Predicates
cards.body: Either the property does not exist or the predicate is true.

cards.title: Predicates
cards.body: Non-existing property returns null, which is not equal to anything.

cards.title: Predicates
cards.body: Properties may also be accessed using a dynamically computed property name.

cards.title: Predicates
cards.code:
n.property STARTS WITH 'Tim' OR
n.property ENDS WITH 'n' OR
n.property CONTAINS 'goodie'

cards.title: Predicates
cards.body: String matching.

cards.title: Predicates
cards.body: String regular expression matching.

cards.title: Predicates
cards.body: Ensure the pattern has at least one match.

cards.title: Predicates
cards.body: Exclude matches to (n)-[:KNOWS]->(m) from the result.

cards.title: Predicates
cards.body: Check if an element exists in a list.

cards.title: List predicates
cards.code: all(x IN coll WHERE x.property IS NOT NULL)

cards.title: List predicates
cards.body: Returns true if the predicate is true for all elements in the list.

cards.title: List predicates
cards.code: any(x IN coll WHERE x.property IS NOT NULL)

cards.title: List predicates
cards.body: Returns true if the predicate is true for at least one element in the list.

cards.title: List predicates
cards.code: none(x IN coll WHERE x.property IS NOT NULL)

cards.title: List predicates
cards.body: Returns true if the predicate is false for all elements in the list.

cards.title: List predicates
cards.code: single(x IN coll WHERE x.property IS NOT NULL)

cards.title: List predicates
cards.body: Returns true if the predicate is true for exactly one element in the list.

cards.title: CASE
cards.code:
CASE n.eyes
 WHEN 'blue' THEN 1
 WHEN 'brown' THEN 2
 ELSE 3
END

cards.title: CASE
cards.body: Return THEN value from the matching WHEN value. The ELSE value is optional, and substituted for null if missing.

cards.title: CASE
cards.code:
CASE
 WHEN n.eyes = 'blue' THEN 1
 WHEN n.age < 40 THEN 2
 ELSE 3
END

cards.title: CASE
cards.body: Return THEN value from the first WHEN predicate evaluating to true. Predicates are evaluated in order.

cards.title: List expressions
cards.body: Number of elements in the list.

cards.title: List expressions
cards.body: Reverse the order of the elements in the list.

cards.title: List expressions
cards.body:
head() returns the first, last() the last element of the list. tail() returns all but the first element. All return null
for an empty list.

cards.title: List expressions
cards.body: A list of the value of the expression for each element in the original list.

cards.title: List expressions
cards.body: A filtered list of the elements where the predicate is true.

cards.title: List expressions
cards.body: A list comprehension that filters a list and extracts the value of the expression for each element in that list.

cards.title: List expressions
cards.code: reduce(s = "", x IN list | s + x.prop)

cards.title: List expressions
cards.body: Evaluate expression for each element in the list, accumulate the results.

cards.title: Functions
cards.body: The first non-null expression.

cards.title: Functions
cards.body: Milliseconds since midnight, January 1, 1970 UTC.

cards.title: Functions
cards.body: The internal id of the relationship or node.

cards.title: Functions
cards.body: Converts the given input into an integer if possible; otherwise it returns null.

cards.title: Functions
cards.body: Converts the given input into a floating point number if possible; otherwise it returns null.

cards.title: Functions
cards.body: Converts the given input into a boolean if possible; otherwise it returns null.

cards.title: Functions
cards.body: Returns a list of string representations for the property names of a node, relationship, or map.

cards.title: Functions
cards.body: Returns a map containing all the properties of a node or relationship.

cards.title: Path functions
cards.body: The number of relationships in the path.

cards.title: Path functions
cards.body: The nodes in the path as a list.

cards.title: Path functions
cards.body: The relationships in the path as a list.

cards.title: Path functions
cards.body: Extract properties from the nodes in a path.

cards.title: Spatial functions
cards.body: Returns a point in a 2D cartesian coordinate system.

cards.title: Spatial functions
cards.body: Returns a point in a 2D geographic coordinate system, with coordinates specified in decimal degrees.

cards.title: Spatial functions
cards.body: Returns a point in a 3D cartesian coordinate system.

cards.title: Spatial functions
cards.body:
Returns a point in a 3D geographic coordinate system, with latitude and longitude in decimal degrees, and height in
meters.

cards.title: Spatial functions
cards.body:
Returns a floating point number representing the linear distance between two points. The returned units will be the same
as those of the point coordinates, and it will work for both 2D and 3D cartesian points.

cards.title: Spatial functions
cards.body: Returns the geodesic distance between two points in meters. It can be used for 3D geographic points as well.

cards.title: Temporal functions
cards.body: Returns a date parsed from a string.

cards.title: Temporal functions
cards.body: Returns a time with no time zone.

cards.title: Temporal functions
cards.body: Returns a time in a specified time zone.

cards.title: Temporal functions
cards.body: Returns a datetime with no time zone.

cards.title: Temporal functions
cards.body: Returns a datetime in the specified time zone.

cards.title: Temporal functions
cards.body: Transforms 3360000 as a UNIX Epoch time into a normal datetime.

cards.title: Temporal functions
cards.body:
All of the temporal functions can also be called with a map of named components. This example returns a date from year,
month and day components. Each function supports a different set of possible components.

cards.title: Temporal functions
cards.body: Temporal types can be created by combining other types. This example creates a datetime from a date and a time.

cards.title: Temporal functions
cards.body:
Temporal types can be created by selecting from more complex types, as well as overriding individual components. This
example creates a date by selecting from a datetime, as well as overriding the day component.

cards.title: Temporal functions
cards.code:
WITH date("2018-04-05") AS d
RETURN d.year, d.month, d.day, d.week, d.dayOfWeek

cards.title: Temporal functions
cards.body: Accessors allow extracting components of temporal types.

cards.title: Duration functions
cards.body: Returns a duration of 1 year, 2 months, 10 days, 12 hours, 45 minutes and 30.25 seconds.

cards.title: Duration functions
cards.body: Returns a duration between two temporal instances.

cards.title: Duration functions
cards.code:
WITH duration("P1Y2M10DT12H45M") AS d
RETURN d.years, d.months, d.days, d.hours, d.minutes

cards.title: Duration functions
cards.body: Returns 1 year, 14 months, 10 days, 12 hours and 765 minutes.

cards.title: Duration functions
cards.code:
WITH duration("P1Y2M10DT12H45M") AS d
RETURN d.years, d.monthsOfYear, d.days, d.hours, d.minutesOfHour

cards.title: Duration functions
cards.body: Returns 1 year, 2 months, 10 days, 12 hours and 45 minutes.

cards.title: Duration functions
cards.body: Returns a date of 2016-02-02. It is also possible to subtract durations from temporal instances.

cards.title: Duration functions
cards.body: Returns a duration of 5 minutes. It is also possible to divide a duration by a number.

cards.title: Mathematical functions
cards.body: The absolute value.

cards.title: Mathematical functions
cards.body:
Returns a random number in the range from 0 (inclusive) to 1 (exclusive), [0,1). Returns a new value for each call. Also
useful for selecting a subset or random ordering.

cards.title: Mathematical functions
cards.body: Round to the nearest integer; ceil() and floor() find the next integer up or down.

cards.title: Mathematical functions
cards.body: The square root.

cards.title: Mathematical functions
cards.body: 0 if zero, -1 if negative, 1 if positive.

cards.title: Mathematical functions
cards.body:
Trigonometric functions also include cos(), tan(), cot(), asin(), acos(), atan(), atan2(), and haversin(). All arguments
for the trigonometric functions should be in radians, if not otherwise specified.

cards.title: Mathematical functions
cards.body: Converts radians into degrees; use radians() for the reverse, and pi() for π.

cards.title: Mathematical functions
cards.body: Logarithm base 10, natural logarithm, e to the power of the parameter, and the value of e.

cards.title: String functions
cards.body: String representation of the expression.

cards.title: String functions
cards.body: Replace all occurrences of search with replacement. All arguments must be expressions.

cards.title: String functions
cards.body: Get part of a string. The subLength argument is optional.

cards.title: String functions
cards.body: The first part of a string. The last part of the string.

cards.title: String functions
cards.body: Trim all whitespace, or on the left or right side.

cards.title: String functions
cards.body: UPPERCASE and lowercase.

cards.title: String functions
cards.body: Split a string into a list of strings.

cards.title: String functions
cards.body: Reverse a string.

cards.title: String functions
cards.body: Calculate the number of characters in the string.

cards.title: Relationship functions
cards.body: String representation of the relationship type.

cards.title: Relationship functions
cards.body: Start node of the relationship.

cards.title: Relationship functions
cards.body: End node of the relationship.

cards.title: Relationship functions
cards.body: The internal id of the relationship.

cards.title: Aggregating functions
cards.body: The number of matching rows.

cards.title: Aggregating functions
cards.body: The number of non-null values.

cards.title: Aggregating functions
cards.body: All aggregating functions also take the DISTINCT operator, which removes duplicates from the values.

cards.title: Aggregating functions
cards.body: List from the values, ignores null.

cards.title: Aggregating functions
cards.body: Sum numerical values. Similar functions are avg(), min(), max().

cards.title: Aggregating functions
cards.body: Discrete percentile. Continuous percentile is percentileCont(). The percentile argument is from 0.0 to 1.0.

cards.title: Aggregating functions
cards.body: Standard deviation for a sample of a population. For an entire population use stDevP().

cards.title: INDEX
cards.body: Create an index on nodes with label Person and property name.

cards.title: INDEX
cards.body: Create an index on relationships with type KNOWS and property since with the name index_name.

cards.title: INDEX
cards.code:
CREATE INDEX FOR (p:Person) ON (p.surname)
OPTIONS {indexProvider: 'native-btree-1.0', indexConfig: {`spatial.cartesian.min`: [-100.0, -100.0], `spatial.cartesian.max`: [100.0, 100.0]}}

cards.title: INDEX
cards.body:
Create an index on nodes with label Person and property surname with the index provider native-btree-1.0 and given
spatial.cartesian settings. The other index settings will have their default values.

cards.title: INDEX
cards.body:
Create a composite index on nodes with label Person and the properties name and age, throws an error if the index
already exist.

cards.title: INDEX
cards.code: CREATE INDEX IF NOT EXISTS FOR (p:Person) ON (p.name, p.age)

cards.title: INDEX
cards.body:
Create a composite index on nodes with label Person and the properties name and age if it does not already exist, does
nothing if it did exist.

cards.title: INDEX
cards.code: CREATE LOOKUP INDEX lookup_index_name FOR (n) ON EACH labels(n)

cards.title: INDEX
cards.body: Create a token lookup index with the name lookup_index_name on nodes with any label .

cards.title: INDEX
cards.code: CREATE LOOKUP INDEX FOR ()-[r]-() ON EACH type(r)

cards.title: INDEX
cards.body: Create a token lookup index on relationships with any relationship type.

cards.title: INDEX
cards.code:
CREATE FULLTEXT INDEX node_fulltext_index_name FOR (n:Friend) ON EACH [n.name]
OPTIONS {indexConfig: {`fulltext.analyzer`: 'swedish'}}

cards.title: INDEX
cards.body:
Create a fulltext index on nodes with the name node_fulltext_index_name and analyzer swedish. Fulltext indexes on nodes
can only be used by from the procedure db.index.fulltext.queryNodes. The other index settings will have their default
values.

cards.title: INDEX
cards.code: CREATE FULLTEXT INDEX rel_fulltext_index_name FOR ()-[r:HAS_PET|BROUGHT_PET]-() ON EACH [r.since, r.price]

cards.title: INDEX
cards.body:
Create a fulltext index on relationships with the name rel_fulltext_index_name. Fulltext indexes on relationships can
only be used by from the procedure db.index.fulltext.queryRelationships.

cards.title: INDEX
cards.body: List all indexes.

cards.title: INDEX
cards.body:
An index can be automatically used for the equality comparison. Note that for example toLower(n.name) = $value will not
use an index.

cards.title: INDEX
cards.body: An index can automatically be used for the IN list checks.

cards.title: INDEX
cards.body:
A composite index can be automatically used for equality comparison of both properties. Note that there needs to be
predicates on all properties of the composite index for it to be used.

cards.title: INDEX
cards.code:
MATCH (n:Person)
USING INDEX n:Person(name)
WHERE n.name = $value

cards.title: INDEX
cards.body: Index usage can be enforced when Cypher uses a suboptimal index, or more than one index should be used.

cards.title: INDEX
cards.body: Drop the index named index_name, throws an error if the index does not exist.

cards.title: INDEX
cards.body: Drop the index named index_name if it exists, does nothing if it does not exist.

cards.title: CONSTRAINT
cards.code:
CREATE CONSTRAINT ON (p:Person)
       ASSERT p.name IS UNIQUE

cards.title: CONSTRAINT
cards.body:
Create a unique property constraint on the label Person and property name. If any other node with that label is updated
or created with a name that already exists, the write operation will fail. This constraint will create an accompanying
index.

cards.title: CONSTRAINT
cards.code:
CREATE CONSTRAINT uniqueness ON (p:Person)
       ASSERT p.age IS UNIQUE

cards.title: CONSTRAINT
cards.body:
Create a unique property constraint on the label Person and property age with the name uniqueness. If any other node
with that label is updated or created with a age that already exists, the write operation will fail. This constraint
will create an accompanying index.

cards.title: CONSTRAINT
CONSTRAINT
cards.body:
Create a unique property constraint on the label Person and property surname with the index provider native-btree-1.0
for the accompanying index.

cards.title: CONSTRAINT
cards.code:
CREATE CONSTRAINT ON (p:Person)
       ASSERT p.name IS NOT NULL

cards.title: CONSTRAINT
cards.body:
(★) Create a node property existence constraint on the label Person and property name, throws an error if the constraint
already exists. If a node with that label is created without a name, or if the name property is removed from an existing
node with the Person label, the write operation will fail.

cards.title: CONSTRAINT
cards.code:
CREATE CONSTRAINT node_exists IF NOT EXISTS ON (p:Person)
       ASSERT p.name IS NOT NULL

cards.title: CONSTRAINT
cards.body:
(★) If a node property existence constraint on the label Person and property name or any constraint with the name
node_exists already exist then nothing happens. If no such constraint exists, then it will be created.

cards.title: CONSTRAINT
cards.code:
CREATE CONSTRAINT ON ()-[l:LIKED]-()
       ASSERT l.when IS NOT NULL

cards.title: CONSTRAINT
cards.body:
(★) Create a relationship property existence constraint on the type LIKED and property when. If a relationship with that
type is created without a when, or if the when property is removed from an existing relationship with the LIKED type,
the write operation will fail.

cards.title: CONSTRAINT
cards.code:
CREATE CONSTRAINT relationship_exists ON ()-[l:LIKED]-()
       ASSERT l.since IS NOT NULL

cards.title: CONSTRAINT
cards.body:
(★) Create a relationship property existence constraint on the type LIKED and property since with the name
relationship_exists. If a relationship with that type is created without a since, or if the since property is removed
from an existing relationship with the LIKED type, the write operation will fail.

cards.title: CONSTRAINT
cards.body: List all unique constraints.

cards.title: CONSTRAINT
cards.code:
CREATE CONSTRAINT ON (p:Person)
      ASSERT (p.firstname, p.surname) IS NODE KEY

cards.title: CONSTRAINT
cards.body:
(★) Create a node key constraint on the label Person and properties firstname and surname. If a node with that label is
created without both firstname and surname or if the combination of the two is not unique, or if the firstname and/or
surname labels on an existing node with the Person label is modified to violate these constraints, the write operation
will fail.

cards.title: CONSTRAINT
cards.code:
CREATE CONSTRAINT node_key ON (p:Person)
      ASSERT (p.name, p.surname) IS NODE KEY

cards.title: CONSTRAINT
cards.body:
(★) Create a node key constraint on the label Person and properties name and surname with the name node_key. If a node
with that label is created without both name and surname or if the combination of the two is not unique, or if the name
and/or surname labels on an existing node with the Person label is modified to violate these constraints, the write
operation will fail.

cards.title: CONSTRAINT
CONSTRAINT
cards.body:
(★) Create a node key constraint on the label Person and properties name and age with the name node_key_with_config and
given spatial.wgs-84 settings for the accompanying index. The other index settings will have their default values.

cards.title: CONSTRAINT
cards.body: Drop the constraint with the name uniqueness, throws an error if the constraint does not exist.

cards.title: CONSTRAINT
cards.body: Drop the constraint with the name uniqueness if it exists, does nothing if it does not exist.

cards.title: Performance
cards.body: • Use parameters instead of literals when possible. This allows Cypher to re-use your queries instead of having to parse

cards.title: Performance
cards.body: and build new execution plans.

cards.title: Performance
cards.body: • Always set an upper limit for your variable length patterns. It’s possible to have a query go wild and touch all nodes

cards.title: Performance
cards.body: in a graph by mistake.

cards.title: Performance
cards.body: • Return only the data you need. Avoid returning whole nodes and relationships — instead, pick the data you need and

cards.title: Performance
cards.body: return only that.

cards.title: Performance
cards.body: • Use `PROFILE` / `EXPLAIN` to analyze the performance of your queries. See

cards.title: Performance
cards.body:
[Query Tuning](https://neo4j.com/docs/cypher-manual/4.3/query-tuning) for more information on these and other topics,
such as planner hints.

cards.title: Database management
cards.body:
(★) Create a database named myDatabase. If a database with that name exists, then the existing database is deleted and a
new one created.

cards.title: Database management
cards.body: (★) Stop the database myDatabase.

cards.title: Database management
cards.body: (★) Start the database myDatabase.

cards.title: Database management
cards.body: List all databases in the system and information about them.

cards.title: Database management
cards.code:
SHOW DATABASES
YIELD name, currentStatus
WHERE name CONTAINS 'my' AND currentStatus = 'online'

cards.title: Database management
cards.body: List information about databases, filtered by name and online status and further refined by conditions on these.

cards.title: Database management
cards.body: List information about the database myDatabase.

cards.title: Database management
cards.body: List information about the default database.

cards.title: Database management
cards.body: List information about the current users home database.

cards.title: Database management
cards.body: (★) Delete the database myDatabase, if it exists.

cards.title: User management
cards.body: Create a new user and a password. This password must be changed on the first login.

cards.title: User management
cards.code: ALTER USER alice SET PASSWORD $password CHANGE NOT REQUIRED

cards.title: User management
cards.body: Set a new password for a user. This user will not be required to change this password on the next login.

cards.title: User management
cards.code: ALTER USER alice IF EXISTS SET PASSWORD CHANGE REQUIRED

cards.title: User management
cards.body: If the specified user exists, force this user to change their password on the next login.

cards.title: User management
cards.code: ALTER USER alice SET STATUS SUSPENDED

cards.title: User management
cards.body: (★) Change the user status to suspended. Use SET STATUS ACTIVE to reactivate the user.

cards.title: User management
cards.code: ALTER USER alice SET HOME DATABASE otherDb

cards.title: User management
cards.body:
(★) Change the home database of user to otherDb. Use REMOVE HOME DATABASE to unset the home database for the user and
fallback to the default database.

cards.title: User management
cards.code: ALTER CURRENT USER SET PASSWORD FROM $old TO $new

cards.title: User management
cards.body: Change the password of the logged-in user. The user will not be required to change this password on the next login.

cards.title: User management
cards.body:
List the currently logged-in user, their status, roles and whether they need to change their password. (★) Status and
roles are Enterprise Edition only.

cards.title: User management
cards.body:
List all users in the system, their status, roles and if they need to change their password. (★) Status and roles are
Enterprise Edition only.

cards.title: User management
cards.code:
SHOW USERS
YIELD user, suspended
WHERE suspended = true

cards.title: User management
cards.body:
List users in the system, filtered by their name and status and further refined by whether they are suspended. (★)
Status is Enterprise Edition only.

cards.title: User management
cards.body: Rename the user alice to alice_delete.

cards.title: User management
cards.body: Delete the user.

cards.title: (★) Role management
cards.body: Create a role.

cards.title: (★) Role management
cards.code: CREATE ROLE my_second_role IF NOT EXISTS AS COPY OF my_role

cards.title: (★) Role management
cards.body: Create a role named my_second_role, unless it already exists, as a copy of the existing my_role.

cards.title: (★) Role management
cards.body: Rename a role named my_second_role to my_other_role.

cards.title: (★) Role management
cards.code: GRANT ROLE my_role, my_other_role TO alice

cards.title: (★) Role management
cards.body: Assign roles to a user.

cards.title: (★) Role management
cards.body: Remove a specified role from a user.

cards.title: (★) Role management
cards.body: List all roles in the system.

cards.title: (★) Role management
cards.code:
SHOW ROLES
YIELD role
WHERE role CONTAINS 'my'

cards.title: (★) Role management
cards.body: List roles, filtered by the name of the role and further refined by whether the name contains 'my'.

cards.title: (★) Role management
cards.body: List all roles that are assigned to at least one user in the system, and the users assigned to those roles.

cards.title: (★) Role management
cards.body: Delete a role.

cards.title: (★) Graph read privileges
cards.code: GRANT TRAVERSE ON GRAPH * NODES * TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Graph read privileges
cards.body: Grant traverse privilege on all nodes and all graphs to a role.

cards.title: (★) Graph read privileges
cards.code: DENY READ {prop} ON GRAPH foo RELATIONSHIP Type TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Graph read privileges
cards.body: Deny read privilege on a specified property, on all relationships with a specified type in a specified graph, to a role.

cards.title: (★) Graph read privileges
cards.code: GRANT MATCH {*} ON HOME GRAPH ELEMENTS Label TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Graph read privileges
cards.body:
Grant read privilege on all properties and traverse privilege in the home graph, to a role. Here, both privileges apply
to all nodes and relationships with a specified label/type in the graph.

cards.title: (★) Graph write privileges
cards.code: GRANT CREATE ON GRAPH * NODES Label TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Graph write privileges
cards.body: Grant create privilege on all nodes with a specified label in all graphs to a role.

cards.title: (★) Graph write privileges
cards.code: DENY DELETE ON GRAPH neo4j TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Graph write privileges
cards.body: Deny delete privilege on all nodes and relationships in a specified graph to a role.

cards.title: (★) Graph write privileges
cards.code: REVOKE SET LABEL Label ON GRAPH * FROM my_role

cards.title: (★) Graph write privileges
cards.body: Revoke set label privilege for the specified label on all graphs to a role.

cards.title: (★) Graph write privileges
cards.code: GRANT REMOVE LABEL * ON GRAPH foo TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Graph write privileges
cards.body: Grant remove label privilege for all labels on a specified graph to a role.

cards.title: (★) Graph write privileges
cards.code: DENY SET PROPERTY {prop} ON GRAPH foo RELATIONSHIPS Type TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Graph write privileges
cards.body:
Deny set property privilege on a specified property, on all relationships with a specified type in a specified graph, to
a role.

cards.title: (★) Graph write privileges
cards.code: GRANT MERGE {*} ON GRAPH * NODES Label TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Graph write privileges
cards.body: Grant merge privilege on all properties, on all nodes with a specified label in all graphs, to a role.

cards.title: (★) Graph write privileges
cards.code: REVOKE WRITE ON GRAPH * FROM my_role

cards.title: (★) Graph write privileges
cards.body: Revoke write privilege on all graphs from a role.

cards.title: (★) Graph write privileges
cards.code: DENY ALL GRAPH PRIVILEGES ON GRAPH foo TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Graph write privileges
cards.body: Deny all graph privileges privilege on a specified graph to a role.

cards.title: (★) SHOW PRIVILEGES
cards.body: List all privileges in the system as Cypher commands.

cards.title: (★) SHOW PRIVILEGES
cards.body: List all privileges in the system, and the roles that they are assigned to.

cards.title: (★) SHOW PRIVILEGES
cards.code:
SHOW PRIVILEGES
YIELD role, action, access
WHERE role = 'my_role'

cards.title: (★) SHOW PRIVILEGES
cards.body: List information about privileges, filtered by role, action and access and further refined by the name of the role.

cards.title: (★) SHOW PRIVILEGES
cards.code: SHOW ROLE my_role PRIVILEGES AS COMMANDS

cards.title: (★) SHOW PRIVILEGES
cards.body: List all privileges assigned to a role as Cypher commands.

cards.title: (★) SHOW PRIVILEGES
cards.code: SHOW ROLE my_role, my_second_role PRIVILEGES AS COMMANDS

cards.title: (★) SHOW PRIVILEGES
cards.body: List all privileges assigned to each of the multiple roles as Cypher commands.

cards.title: (★) SHOW PRIVILEGES
cards.code: SHOW USER alice PRIVILEGES AS COMMANDS

cards.title: (★) SHOW PRIVILEGES
cards.body: List all privileges of a user, and the role that they are assigned to as Cypher commands.

cards.title: (★) SHOW PRIVILEGES
cards.body: List all privileges of the currently logged in user, and the role that they are assigned to as Cypher commands.

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.code: GRANT ACCESS ON DATABASE * TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.body: Grant privilege to access and run queries against all databases to a role.

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.code: GRANT START ON DATABASE * TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.body: Grant privilege to start all databases to a role.

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.code: GRANT STOP ON DATABASE * TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.body: Grant privilege to stop all databases to a role.

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.code: GRANT CREATE INDEX ON DATABASE foo TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.body: Grant privilege to create indexes on a specified database to a role.

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.code: GRANT DROP INDEX ON DATABASE foo TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.body: Grant privilege to drop indexes on a specified database to a role.

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.code: GRANT SHOW INDEX ON DATABASE * TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.body: Grant privilege to show indexes on all databases to a role.

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.code: DENY INDEX MANAGEMENT ON DATABASE bar TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.body: Deny privilege to create and drop indexes on a specified database to a role.

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.code: GRANT CREATE CONSTRAINT ON DATABASE * TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.body: Grant privilege to create constraints on all databases to a role.

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.code: DENY DROP CONSTRAINT ON DATABASE * TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.body: Deny privilege to drop constraints on all databases to a role.

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.code: DENY SHOW CONSTRAINT ON DATABASE foo TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.body: Deny privilege to show constraints on a specified database to a role.

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.code: REVOKE CONSTRAINT ON DATABASE * FROM my_role

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.body: Revoke granted and denied privileges to create and drop constraints on all databases from a role.

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.code: GRANT CREATE NEW LABELS ON DATABASE * TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.body: Grant privilege to create new labels on all databases to a role.

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.code: DENY CREATE NEW TYPES ON DATABASE foo TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.body: Deny privilege to create new relationship types on a specified database to a role.

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.code: REVOKE GRANT CREATE NEW PROPERTY NAMES ON DATABASE bar FROM my_role

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.body: Revoke the grant privilege to create new property names on a specified database from a role.

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.code: GRANT NAME MANAGEMENT ON HOME DATABASE TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.body: Grant privilege to create labels, relationship types, and property names on the home database to a role.

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.code: GRANT ALL ON DATABASE baz TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.body:
Grant privilege to access, create and drop indexes and constraints, create new labels, types and property names on a
specified database to a role.

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.code: GRANT SHOW TRANSACTION (*) ON DATABASE foo TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.body: Grant privilege to list transactions and queries from all users on a specified database to a role.

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.code: DENY TERMINATE TRANSACTION (user1, user2) ON DATABASES * TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.body: Deny privilege to kill transactions and queries from user1 and user2 on all databases to a role.

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.code: REVOKE GRANT TRANSACTION MANAGEMENT ON HOME DATABASE FROM my_role

cards.title: (★) Database privileges
cards.body: Revoke the granted privilege to list and kill transactions and queries from all users on the home database from a role.

cards.title: (★) Role management privileges
cards.code: GRANT CREATE ROLE ON DBMS TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Role management privileges
cards.body: Grant the privilege to create roles to a role.

cards.title: (★) Role management privileges
cards.code: GRANT RENAME ROLE ON DBMS TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Role management privileges
cards.body: Grant the privilege to rename roles to a role.

cards.title: (★) Role management privileges
cards.code: GRANT DROP ROLE ON DBMS TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Role management privileges
cards.body: Grant the privilege to delete roles to a role.

cards.title: (★) Role management privileges
cards.code: DENY ASSIGN ROLE ON DBMS TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Role management privileges
cards.body: Deny the privilege to assign roles to users to a role.

cards.title: (★) Role management privileges
cards.code: DENY REMOVE ROLE ON DBMS TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Role management privileges
cards.body: Deny the privilege to remove roles from users to a role.

cards.title: (★) Role management privileges
cards.code: REVOKE DENY SHOW ROLE ON DBMS FROM my_role

cards.title: (★) Role management privileges
cards.body: Revoke the denied privilege to show roles from a role.

cards.title: (★) Role management privileges
cards.code: GRANT ROLE MANAGEMENT ON DBMS TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Role management privileges
cards.body: Grant all privileges to manage roles to a role.

cards.title: (★) User management privileges
cards.code: GRANT CREATE USER ON DBMS TO my_role

cards.title: (★) User management privileges
cards.body: Grant the privilege to create users to a role.

cards.title: (★) User management privileges
cards.code: GRANT RENAME USER ON DBMS TO my_role

cards.title: (★) User management privileges
cards.body: Grant the privilege to rename users to a role.

cards.title: (★) User management privileges
cards.code: DENY ALTER USER ON DBMS TO my_role

cards.title: (★) User management privileges
cards.body: Deny the privilege to alter users to a role.

cards.title: (★) User management privileges
cards.code: REVOKE SET PASSWORDS ON DBMS FROM my_role

cards.title: (★) User management privileges
cards.body: Revoke the granted and denied privileges to alter users' passwords from a role.

cards.title: (★) User management privileges
cards.code: REVOKE GRANT SET USER STATUS ON DBMS FROM my_role

cards.title: (★) User management privileges
cards.body: Revoke the granted privilege to alter the account status of users from a role.

cards.title: (★) User management privileges
cards.code: GRANT SET USER HOME DATABASE ON DBMS TO my_role

cards.title: (★) User management privileges
cards.body: Grant the privilege alter the home database of users to a role.

cards.title: (★) User management privileges
cards.code: GRANT DROP USER ON DBMS TO my_role

cards.title: (★) User management privileges
cards.body: Grant the privilege to delete users to a role.

cards.title: (★) User management privileges
cards.code: REVOKE DENY SHOW USER ON DBMS FROM my_role

cards.title: (★) User management privileges
cards.body: Revoke the denied privilege to show users from a role.

cards.title: (★) User management privileges
cards.code: GRANT USER MANAGEMENT ON DBMS TO my_role

cards.title: (★) User management privileges
cards.body: Grant all privileges to manage users to a role.

cards.title: (★) Database management privileges
cards.code: GRANT CREATE DATABASE ON DBMS TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Database management privileges
cards.body: Grant the privilege to create databases to a role.

cards.title: (★) Database management privileges
cards.code: REVOKE DENY DROP DATABASE ON DBMS FROM my_role

cards.title: (★) Database management privileges
cards.body: Revoke the denied privilege to delete databases from a role.

cards.title: (★) Database management privileges
cards.code: DENY DATABASE MANAGEMENT ON DBMS TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Database management privileges
cards.body: Deny all privileges to manage database to a role.

cards.title: (★) Privilege management privileges
cards.code: GRANT SHOW PRIVILEGE ON DBMS TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Privilege management privileges
cards.body: Grant the privilege to show privileges to a role.

cards.title: (★) Privilege management privileges
cards.code: DENY ASSIGN PRIVILEGE ON DBMS TO my_role

cards.title: (★) Privilege management privileges
cards.body: Deny the privilege to assign privileges to roles to a role.

cards.title: (★) Privilege management privileges
cards.code: REVOKE GRANT REMOVE PRIVILEGE ON DBMS FROM my_role

cards.title: (★) Privilege management privileges
cards.body: Revoke the granted privilege to remove privileges from roles from a role.

cards.title: (★) Privilege management privileges
cards.code: REVOKE PRIVILEGE MANAGEMENT ON DBMS FROM my_role

cards.title: (★) Privilege management privileges
cards.body: Revoke all granted and denied privileges for manage privileges from a role.

cards.title: (★) DBMS privileges
cards.code: GRANT ALL ON DBMS TO my_role

cards.title: (★) DBMS privileges
cards.body: Grant privilege to perform all role management, user management, database management and privilege management to a role.

cards.title: ★ Note
cards.body: (★) Functionality available in Neo4j Enterprise Edition.
